data.text:
YEMI

I donâ€™t take afternoon naps. They give me all sorts of weird dreams. I always wake up sapped and cranky. I prefer morning naps. Iâ€™d stay awake all night, working, and then I go for a run by 5 a.m., come back and have breakfast, and finally crash until 2 p.m. My normal daily routine.

But a clientâ€™s job keeps me awake all night, eating into my morning routine until 12 noon. Exhausted, I throw myself on my bed and pass out. Of course, I fall into one of those random dreams. And it makes no sense to me while Iâ€™m dreaming it. When I wake up some minutes after 6 p.m., all of it disappears from memory. I can literally see it vanish from my head as I try to put the pieces together.

I go for a shower and cook myself a meal. It isnâ€™t until after I sit to watch some TV that I realize Halim has been gone all day. I go back and forth on the decision to call her. I donâ€™t want her to take it as something other than what it is. Iâ€™m just a roommate worried about a fellow roommate.

Maybe roommate is not the right word.

Flat mate? Housemate? Tenant?

Just call her and ask if sheâ€™s okay.

I dial her number. It rings. She doesnâ€™t answer. I dump my phone aside. At least, I tried. I face the TV again, switching through channels. Nothing interesting. I turn it off, put on some jazz music and pick Toni Kanâ€™s The Carnivorous City. I hope I enjoy it as I did Igoni Barretâ€™s Blackass.

The front door opens and I lower the book to have a look at the strange woman that has just walked into the house.

â€œHey roomie!â€

I spring to a sitting position. â€œHalim?â€

She is all smiles and all sorts of different. Short hair, makeup, glowing skin, multiple ear piercings and a dress made for a goddess.

â€œHow do I look?â€

Iâ€™m dumbstruck. No, Iâ€™m not speaking metaphorically. I am actually dumbstruck. I canâ€™t even work up a single thought.

â€œHi.â€ She waves. â€œIs Yemi there?â€

Iâ€™m still wordless.

â€œYou like?â€ she asks.

â€œWh-what did you do to your hair? And all those piercingsâ€¦ Whatâ€™s that all about?â€

She loses her smile.

â€œNo, no, no, no! Donâ€™t do your face like that. You look great. Really, you do.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t like it?â€

â€œI do. Itâ€™s just that you had so much hair.â€

â€œI know but I didnâ€™t know what to do with it. Sha, thanks for making me feel better.â€

She begins towards her room, taking a bunch of shopping bags along.

â€œIâ€™m sorry!â€ I say.

â€œSorry for what?â€

I walk to her door. I stop when I see her taking off her dress. Sheâ€™s left only in her underwear. When she sees me, she shows no reaction.

â€œOkay, you want me to be honest?â€

â€œNo,â€ she answers. â€œIf you say anything, itâ€™ll be worse.â€

â€œI like the new look, Halim. Itâ€™s different, and the more I stare at you, the more Iâ€™m liking it. You have beautiful hair, long or short.â€

She gives me a doubtful look.

â€œIâ€™m being honest here.â€

â€œThanks for the honesty.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s with the piercings, though?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t do them today. Theyâ€™ve been there. I stopped showing them off when I became dedicated to church.â€

â€œAnd now, theyâ€™re back.â€

She slumps on her bed. â€œI miss my old life. I want to be me again. Is that a bad thing?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œDo you like me like this? With all the piercings and crazy hairstyle and noise?â€

â€œNoise?â€

â€œI get really talkative and animated and clingy and many other things.â€

â€œI donâ€™t mind.â€

â€œI did a tattoo as well,â€ she whispers.

â€œFor real?â€

â€œYou should have seen the face of the artist when he was done and I told him I was HIV positive. He looked like I had taken Ebola and shoved it down his throat.â€

She laughs out loud. I smile, watching her. Itâ€™s the first time Iâ€™ve seen her laugh like this. Itâ€™s not infectious; itâ€™s entertaining. Like sheâ€™s in her own bubble. And her mirth brings tears to her eyes.

â€œHe used gloves, though?â€

â€œYes. But he was angry at me, telling me I should have told him from the start.â€

â€œYou should have, Halim. Any mishap could have happened.â€

â€œI know but it didnâ€™t really occur to me to tell him. For the first time since I got diagnosed, I didnâ€™t see myself as an HIV patient. I just saw myself as a normal girl.â€

â€œWoman,â€ I correct wittily.

â€œOh, let me be a girl today.â€

â€œSo, how did it end with him? The tattoo guy.â€

â€œI asked him if he was irritated because I was HIV positive. He couldnâ€™t answer. So, I gave him a little talk about living with HIV and what it feels like, as opposed to what people on the outside think it feels like. You should have seen me. Youâ€™d have been proud, counselor.â€

â€œI am proud now. Youâ€™ve finally fallen into acceptance.â€

â€œI think so.â€

She pulls a plastic bag towards her. â€œI know you donâ€™t like eating snacks and meals cooked from outside but you like boli, donâ€™t you?â€

â€œYup.â€

â€œOya, come and eat. I was in a cab on my way back and saw this woman near Water Corporation, roasting plantain and yam, the Port Harcourt way. I had to stop the cab and join the queue. So, I got us boli, beans, roasted yam, roasted potatoes and kpanla.â€

â€œAwesome,â€ I say, walking to her bed. She hands me a food pack and we sit to eat. She opens up to me, telling me stories from her childhood, the schools she went to, her relationship with Eben, and also her faith. Good Lord! She does talk!

â€œDo you want to go back to Eben?â€ I inquire as we come to the end of the meal. Sheâ€™s eating the head of the kpanla fish, which in my opinion is the best part. I love women who love fish head.

â€œWill I go back to him? No. I canâ€™t say I was really in love with him. I liked him, and I think I would have fallen in love along the way, but it wasnâ€™t that type of butterflies in your tummy kind of love.â€

â€œHave you ever felt that before?â€

â€œYeah. A little. With Paul. I had a huge crush on him. I think, generally, the problem is with me. I donâ€™t know how to fall in love.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t know how to fall in love?â€

â€œNo.â€ She scratches her nose with the back of her hand, showing me a collection of rings on her fingers that match her new personality. Iâ€™m going crazy for her by the second.

â€œI fall in love slowly, gradually,â€ she explains. â€œItâ€™s not a precaution thing. Itâ€™s just me. Iâ€™m wired differently. But I want to have that type of spontaneous, overnight, head-over-heels, struck-by-lightning kind of love. You think Iâ€™ll ever find that?â€

â€œYou might.â€

Her phone starts to ring. Itâ€™s resting on her bag beside her. She looks at it. â€œItâ€™s my mom,â€ she reveals, her back slouching into a curve. â€œEben must have given her my number. I really miss her sha. Thereâ€™s some kindness in my heart this night, and a sweet, soft voice telling me that itâ€™s okay to pick her call.â€

â€œYou should.â€

â€œBut my hands are all oily. How did you manage to eat our own fish head with just one hand?â€

The phone rings out.

â€œOh well. Sheâ€™ll call back.â€

The phone lights up again. I reach out and press the answer button.

â€œPlease put her on speakerphone,â€ Halim whispers. I thumb on the button.

â€œHalim?â€ her mother calls.

â€œYes?â€

â€œHalim?â€ her mother repeats, disbelief in her voice.

â€œAunty Ada, good evening.â€

â€œHalimnye, is this you?â€

Halim doesnâ€™t answer. The woman begins to give thanks to God while Halim maintains her hush, hiding her emotions with a plain face.

â€œHow are you, darling? Where are you? Are you okay? Are you fine? How are you feeling?â€

â€œIâ€™m fine, Aunty Ada. Stop being so hysterical.â€

Her motherâ€™s tone turns weepy. â€œIâ€™ve been so worried about you, but Iâ€™ll get your texts and feel better, and start worrying again. Itâ€™s been torture, my baby. How are you? Talk to your mom.â€

â€œIâ€™m alive.â€

â€œEben says youâ€™re still in Lagos. Can I come and see you?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œOkay. How about coming over? I just need to see you, darling. Please. Will you come for the Christmas holiday? Or maybe we can travel out. I read this article online that says there are forty-two places Nigerians can visit without a visa. Two of us can just travel to one of those countries and stretch our legs at some beach and ogle exotic menâ€¦â€

Halim winces. â€œOkay, Aunty Ada, I have to go. Merry Christmas in advance. I love you!â€

â€œI love you tooâ€¦â€

â€œAnd please donâ€™t call me tomorrow.â€

She presses an oily finger on her phone before stabbing it at her tear duct to ward off a tear. The result is a scream.

â€œPepper!â€ she cries. â€œYemi, pepper!â€

â€œLetâ€™s get you to the bathroom.â€

I help her up from the bed and lead her to her bathroom. Splashing water over her eye, I try to manage the situation, but I donâ€™t seem to be helping. On closer examination, I spot a particle in the eye. I go for a sachet of water from the kitchen and hose out the foreign object.

â€œAre you better?â€ I ask.

â€œYes.â€ She breathes out. â€œThank you.â€

I realize our bodies are in contact. Her hand is on my shoulder and my arm holds onto her waist protectively. I step back, as does she. We return to her bedroom where she passes me a shopping bag. I look at her for a few seconds longer before taking the bag. I have a peep inside and lift my face in surprise.

â€œIâ€™m confused.â€ I shake my head. â€œThis is expensive, Halim. Why?â€

She shrugs. â€œYouâ€™ve been kind to me. And you donâ€™t even know me. This is just me saying thank you.â€

â€œWhere did you get the money from?â€

â€œIâ€™m rich, remember?â€

I smile. â€œI donâ€™t know what to say, Halim. Thank you doesnâ€™t seem enough.â€

â€œItâ€™ll do.â€

I take her by surprise, grabbing her by the arms and pulling her in for a hug. â€œThank you.â€

She pushes away. My eyes rest on her lips briefly. She spins away from me and heads back to her bed.

â€œA butterfly tattoo?â€

She slaps both hands on her butt cheeks, giggling.

â€œItâ€™s actually artsy,â€ I mutter.

She picks her shawl off the bed and wraps around her waist. â€œI just felt like doing something daring.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad you did. And Iâ€™m happy to see this side of you. Your sad eyes are gone.â€

â€œReally?â€

â€œYes. Can I try on the sneakers?â€

â€œYeah.â€

I sit on the floor. She watches as I slip my feet into the designer pair. â€œTheyâ€™re perfect, Halim. I should go out on a date with them.â€

â€œYou want to date them? Yemi, I know you have an unhealthy obsession over sneakers but please, donâ€™t date them.â€

I get confused at her words for a couple of seconds and then I catch her meaning. We both fall into mirth at the same time.

â€œI actually meant I should wear them out on a date.â€

â€œYou should.â€

â€œBut I donâ€™t have a date.â€

â€œTake Queen,â€ she teases.

â€œIâ€™d rather take you.â€

â€œMe?â€

â€œWould you say no?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œIs that a no or a yes?â€

â€œNo, I wonâ€™t say no. And no, I donâ€™t mind going out on a date with you, but the problem is I feel itâ€™ll jinx my future dating life.â€

â€œHow?â€

â€œYouâ€™re my housemate. Not a love interest. My first date in Lagos should be with a love interest. Yemi, donâ€™t come and spoil market for me.â€

â€œWhat if Iâ€™m a love interest?â€

She casts a puzzled gaze at me as laughter springs from her. Iâ€™m about to ask her why sheâ€™s amused when a knock on the front door interrupts me.

â€œIâ€™ll be back.â€

I hurry out to the living room. Iâ€™m expecting a friend to bring over a laptop I want to buy. He is supposed to stay a while for a game or two, but Iâ€™m having such a good time with Halim that I plan to ditch him immediately he drops in.

I open the door with a lie already on my lips. But I freeze at the sight before me.

â€œHi Yemi.â€

Iâ€™m greeted by a gorgeous lady, who is dressed in a garb ensemble. She has a male companion with her. I look at them both and my mood curdles. I slam the door in their faces.

â€œWhoâ€™s that?â€ Halim asks, her head poking out from her bedroom.

â€œMy ex and my cousin.â€

She stares at me questioningly. â€œThe cousin you said was coming and wasnâ€™t coming again?â€

â€œNo. This is another one. My ex dumped me for him after she got pregnant with his baby. They got married.â€

â€œOuch.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re outside.â€

Another knock hits the door.

â€œWhat do they want?â€

â€œIâ€™m about to find out.â€

I turn around and open the door a second time.

HALIM

â€œYemi, please, let us in. We need to talk.â€

I take in as much of Yemiâ€™s cousin and his ex as I can before I retreat to my room. The cousin is a lighter version of him. Shorter too. Clean appearance. Neat and well-groomed. Not the sort of man one would imagine stealing another manâ€™s woman.

The lady is beautiful, but poorly dressed. Thatâ€™s all I can glean from her. But itâ€™s not my business who they are and what had transpired between them and Yemi.

I take off my underwear. My fingers follow the outlines of the tattoo on my butt which is a little tender. I stare at it in the mirror. Iâ€™ve never really understood my girly obsession with butterflies. I find them vibrant and free, even as fragile as they appear. If Iâ€™d been given a chance to come into this life as anything else, Iâ€™d have chosen to be one of them, I guess. To have an existence that is brief but well-lived trumps a long life with pain and no meaning.

Yemi knocks on my door. I slip into my nightshirt.

â€œCome in.â€

He enters. â€œHalim, I need you, please.â€

â€œYou need me?â€

His face is worn in a frown. â€œYes, I need you or Iâ€™ll kill someone this night.â€

â€œWhoa! Easy.â€

â€œJust come and sit with me, so that I donâ€™t do anything stupid.â€

â€œYemi, I think itâ€™s a family matterâ€¦â€

â€œWe wonâ€™t take long.â€

â€œI just donâ€™t want to be caught in the crossfire.â€

â€œThere isnâ€™t going to be any crossfire. Just me firing all the shots.â€

I snort.

â€œWhat?â€ he asks.

â€œItâ€™s just the figure of speech youâ€™re usingâ€¦â€

â€œHalim?â€

â€œLetâ€™s go.â€

He begins out. I follow him into the living room.

â€œHalim, meet Alex and Oluwatosin,â€ he introduces.

â€œHi,â€ I greet. Alex is the lady. Oluwatosin is his cousin.

Yemi takes the two-sitter that faces the long sofa on which the couple is seated. I occupy the space beside him. He stretches his long legs on the center table, crossing one foot over the other. The price tag of the sneakers sticks out.

â€œSo, letâ€™s go back to how our conversation started,â€ he speaks. â€œYou came in, we exchanged greetings, I asked why you were here and you said you wanted to talk, to ask my forgivenessâ€¦right?â€

â€œYes.â€ Alex slants forward.

â€œSo, go ahead. Ask on.â€

â€œYemi, I hurt you. I did a very terrible thing to you. We did a terrible thing and we are sorry. Weâ€™re here to ask your forgiveness. Please, find it in your heart to pardon us, to let it all go.â€

Two large tears run down her cheeks. I look at Yemi. He seems unmoved. He is clearly angry. But I also see an expression of pleasure on his face. The lady tugs at the flaps of the sweater sheâ€™s wearing which is responsible for the drabness on her. If it was a brighter color, she would have appeared livelier.

â€œIs your husband sorry?â€ Yemi asks.

â€œWhat?â€ Alex sniffles.

â€œThat bastard seated beside you. Is he sorry?â€

Yemiâ€™s cousinâ€™s face is passive. He comes off as a proud man. His wife nudges him. He looks away from staring at the television and faces Yemi.

â€œWe both apologize,â€ he states in a gruff tone.

â€œAfter six years?â€

â€œYou went away, Yemi. No one knew where you were. You changed lines and deleted all your social media accounts.â€

I stare at Yemi, surprised to hear that he had once walked a mile in my shoes.

â€œAfter six years, we just got info on youâ€“â€

â€œBullshit,â€ Yemi interjects. â€œYou expect me to believe that youâ€™re here just to say youâ€™re sorry?â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œThen Iâ€™ve heard you! Get the hell out of my house!â€

Alex glances at her husband.

â€œGet out,â€ Yemi repeats.

â€œActually, thereâ€™s more,â€ Alex confesses.

â€œI knew it. Two of you are the most selfish ingrates I ever met in my life. There is just no way youâ€™re coming here after six years just to say youâ€™re sorry for what youâ€™ve done.â€

â€œYemi,â€ Alex says. â€œThe baby I was carrying for Tosin when you leftâ€¦ The baby died. I had a stillbirth.â€

My heart tugs. â€œSorry about that,â€ I murmur. Yemi eyes me.

â€œThank you,â€ Alex replies. â€œBut that was just beginning. I had two other miscarriages, and then stopped getting pregnant entirely. The doctors say thereâ€™s nothing wrong with us, so theyâ€™re not sure why we are having difficulty with pregnancy.â€

â€œWhere is this pathetic story going?â€

â€œWellâ€¦everyone thinks youâ€™re responsible for our childlessnessâ€¦â€

Yemi drops his legs from the table. â€œAre you out of your mind?!â€ he shouts. â€œAfter all you have done, Alex! After how you hurt me and turned my generosity on my face! After everything, you now accuse me of being diabolic?!â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ she weeps.

â€œMy family took you in because you had no one! I convinced my parents to welcome you into their home as one of their daughters! I loved you! I took care of you! But the best way you repaid me was to cheat on me with my cousin and get pregnant for him! All under the one month I was away from you!â€

Alex covers her face with her sweater.

â€œYou then turn my family against me and marry the bastard father of your child! And now, youâ€™re blaming me for your childlessness?!â€

â€œShe didnâ€™t exactly say that,â€ Tosin responds.

Yemi charges up. â€œIf you open your mouth to talk to me again, Tosinâ€“!â€

â€œYouâ€™ll do what?!â€ Tosin barks back, also springing up.

â€œTosin!â€ his wife screams, coming in-between them. â€œWhat is wrong with you?! Sit down!â€

Both cousins engage in a glowering contest.

â€œPlease, two of you, sit down,â€ Alex begs. â€œPlease.â€

Tosin takes his seat first. Yemi does the same, after a couple of seconds. Alex also sits.

â€œYemi, I didnâ€™t blame you for it. Itâ€™s just that Iâ€¦ We, the whole family, we feel that itâ€™s because you hold a grudge against us, thatâ€™s why itâ€™s been difficult for us to have a baby. Iâ€™m begging you again to forgive. Iâ€™m two months pregnant and Iâ€™m really scared that Iâ€™ll lose it like all the others. Iâ€™m tired.â€

â€œAre you sure itâ€™s Tosinâ€™s baby?â€ Yemi asks spitefully.

â€œYemi?â€ I scold.

â€œHalim, I have to ask because all sheâ€™s good at is jumping from one man to another. Maybe sheâ€™s now carrying my younger brotherâ€™s kid.â€

Alex begins sobbing again. â€œItâ€™s Tosinâ€™s baby. Yemi, Iâ€™m so sorry for all I did to you. Iâ€™m so sorry.â€

She goes on her knees. â€œPlease, find it in your heart to forgive me. I donâ€™t deserve it, but I need it desperately.â€ She places her hand over her tummy. â€œIf I lose this one Iâ€™ll die. Iâ€™m sorry, Yemi.â€

I notice that Yemi has gone soft. â€œGet up, Alex.â€

â€œNo. Not until you say you forgive me.â€

â€œYou think itâ€™s that easy? Do you know what you did to me? How two of you ruined my life? Do you?!â€

â€œYou alone ruined your life,â€ Tosin remarks. â€œYou slept around and got the disease.â€

In a flash, Yemi is upon him with lethal blows.

Alex manages up and tries to go between them but I drag her away for her own safety.

â€œStop it!â€ I scream. Yemi ignores me. Tosin gets an open window to throw in a punch. He hits his mark on Yemiâ€™s eye, dazing him for a second and gaining another opening to continue with his retaliation. They knock down the sofa, falling to the floor, muscled arms and fists enacting pain and injury on each other. They are deaf to our pleas and screams. I find that Iâ€™m crying too, but Iâ€™m suddenly gifted with the commonsense to run out to our next door neighbor for help.

I find the father of the house seated outside, slapping mosquitoes away from his legs. In a jumble of words, I explain the situation. The mention of a pregnant woman pushes him up on his feet and he follows me into the house. We enter to find Yemi seated on Tosin whose only present action is shielding his face from the rain of assaults.

â€œYou wan kill the boy?!â€ my neighbor bellows, bringing Yemiâ€™s actions to a halt. Breathing hard, he rises up from Tosinâ€™s body, staggers into his bedroom and slams the door. Alex rushes to her husbandâ€™s side. He is bruised in a bad way. Our neighbor helps him up. He seems dazed. I rush to get him a cup of water. He takes a sip and taints what is left with his blood.

â€œLetâ€™s go,â€ he instructs his wife.

â€œRelax,â€ all three of us say in unison.

â€œIâ€™m fine.â€

He stands up, sways a little and starts towards the door. Our neighbor follows him out.

â€œThank you,â€ Alex says to me.

â€œTell your husband to report himself to the hospital and explain to them that he might have been exposed to HIV. But the likelihood of him being infected is very slim. Yemiâ€™s viral load is almost negligible. Still, let him report himself.â€

â€œThank you. God bless you,â€ she utters. â€œPlease, speak to Yemi for me. I didnâ€™t know heâ€™d still be this angry after six years. Tell him Iâ€™m very sorry and I mean it.â€

â€œSure.â€

I escort her out and lock the door. I aim for Yemiâ€™s bedroom.

â€œCan I come in?â€ I ask.

â€œYeah.â€

I walk in. Heâ€™s in the bathroom, before the mirror, attending to a cut above his eye. Apart from his torn t-shirt, everything seems fine.

â€œYou told me you wouldnâ€™t do anything stupid,â€ I remind him.

â€œYeah, I lied. But given the chance, Iâ€™d be stupid again.â€

He takes off his t-shirt and dumps it on the floor.

â€œLet me help youâ€¦â€

â€œIâ€™m good,â€ he replies gruffly. I stubbornly pick a pair of adhesive bandages from his First Aid box.

â€œDo you want to talk about what just happened?â€

â€œNothing to talk about.â€ He faces me. â€œYou heard the whole story.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry for what you went through.â€

He doesnâ€™t reply. I cover the cut above his eye and wash my hands.

â€œYemi, breathe easy. Youâ€™re puffing really hard. Calm down.â€

â€œIâ€™m good.â€

He slams a blood-spattered face towel in his laundry basket and stomps out of the bathroom. I follow him out to the living room. He cleans the mess from the scuffle, grunting as he does so. I watch him in amusement. Iâ€™m thinking Tosin needs to return to get more thumps. Yemi doesnâ€™t seem satisfied.

I help him lift the sofa and put it back into place.

â€œGod, Iâ€™m tired,â€ I say in a yawn, dumping my weight on it, just as the electricity goes out. I hiss. Yemi sits on the center table and faces me, turning on a flashlight.

â€œI loved her,â€ he mumbles. His heavy breathing has stopped but his eyes still hold anger.

â€œAlex?â€

â€œWho else? I was a fool for her. She was my first. First love, first everything. My cousin was older, more experienced with womenâ€¦â€

â€œHe lived with you?â€

â€œYeah. My family is huge, cousins, aunties, uncles, distant relatives everywhere. Itâ€™s a big compound. I was a struggling software developer then, trying to put together some money to get my own place so that Alex and I can be alone.â€

â€œHow did you find out about them?â€

â€œI walked in on them. They were in my auntâ€™s apartment, which was in the next compound. They hadnâ€™t expected me to ever go there. And seriously, I donâ€™t even know what took me there, being that that aunt was not my favorite. Iâ€™d just felt like saying hi to her that evening. So I walked in there andâ€¦â€

He shakes his head.

â€œThe funny thing was that I still wanted Alex back, even after everything. Even as she told me she was carrying Tosinâ€™s baby. I wanted her back. But the whole family insisted that she had to marry Tosin, and so they pulled resources together for a traditional wedding.â€

â€œWow. Thatâ€™s cold.â€

â€œYeah. I just gave myself brain, packed my things and left home. Changed my phone number, deleted my life from everyone and moved to Lagos. I was lucky when I got here. A friend said a company was looking for a contract software developer. It was good money. I started on the job and others started trickling in. I got a good apartment, bought a car, and felt the best thing to do was to be a slut. I had more sex than ten men put together would in a year. I did it all. Threesomes, orgies, prostitutesâ€¦â€

Yemi exhales.

â€œI then got this dream job for this big company. One of the perks was work-related trips outside Nigeria. It was a good deal. I got in on the first day of work and had to have all sorts of tests run. A week later, they called me to the clinic and broke the news that I was HIV positive. I was confused. I didnâ€™t believe them. I left the place and went to a general hospital to redo the test. Same result. I still didnâ€™t believe. I did the test again in a private hospitalâ€¦â€

â€œSame result.â€

Yemi nods. â€œI was angry, confusedâ€¦ I locked myself in for two months, starving myself and living off alcohol and cigarettes. I wanted to die. Eventually, I fell really ill and had to swallow my pride to call Clement.â€

I smile. â€œAnd of course, he came through.â€
